SUMMARY: NESTED | FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD DETAIL: FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD

javax.constraints
Interface Problem

public interface Problem

A constraint satisfaction problem Problem can be defined in terms of constrained variables and constraints. The standard will cover the following types of Constrained Variables:

  • Var - Integer Variables
  • VarBool - Boolean Variables
  • VarReal - Real (floating point) Variables
  • VarSet - Set Variables.

The standard will cover the following Constraints:

  • Basic arithmetic and logical constraints
  • Global constraints (defined on collections of variables)
  • Logical combinations of constraints.

Problem Definition is completely independent of the Problem Resolution (class Solver).

See Also:
ConstrainedVariable, Var, Constraint, Solver

allDifferent

Constraint allDifferent(Var[] vars)
Creates and returns a new Constraint stating that all of the elements of the array of variables "vars" must take different values from each other.

Parameters:
vars - the array of Vars which must all take different values.
Returns:
the all-different Constraint on the array of Vars.

cardinality

Constraint cardinality(Var[] vars,
                       int cardValue,
                       Oper oper,
                       int value)
This method creates and returns a new cardinality constraint such as “cardinality(vars,cardValue) < value”. Here “cardinality(vars,cardValue)” denotes a constrained integer variable that is equal to the number of those elements in the array "vars" that are bound to the "cardValue". For example, if “oper” is Oper.LT it means that the variable “cardinality(vars,cardValue)” must be less than the “value”. This constraint does NOT assume a creation of an intermediate variable "cardinality(vars,cardValue)".

cardinality

Constraint cardinality(Var[] vars,
                       int cardValue,
                       Oper oper,
                       Var var)
This method is similar to the one above but instead of “value” the “cardinality(vars,cardValue)” is being constrained by “var”.

cardinality

Constraint cardinality(Var[] vars,
                       Var cardVar,
                       Oper oper,
                       int value)
This method is similar to the one above but instead of “var” it uses "value"

cardinality

                       Var var)
This method is similar to the one above but instead of “cardValue” it uses "cardVar"

constraint

Constraint constraint(java.lang.String name,
                      java.lang.String symbolicExpression)
Creates a Constraint based on the symbolicExpression such as "x*y-z<3*r", adds this constraint to the problem, and returns the newly added Constraint. It is assumed that all variables in the expression were previously created under names used within this expression. If the returned Constraint is null, there is either an error inside the symbolicExpression or there is no concrete solver implementation of this method. In either case, the constraint will not have been added to the problem.

Parameters:
name - the name for a new constraint
symbolicExpression - a string that defines a constrained expression that uses already defined variables, e.g. "x*y-z<3*r"
Returns:
the constraint created and added to the problem, or null if there is an error inside the symbolicExpression or if this method is not defined by a concrete solver implementation.

element

Constraint element(int[] array,
                   Var indexVar,
                   Oper oper,
                   int value)
Returns a constraint: array[indexVar] value Here "array[indexVar]" denotes a constrained integer variable, which domain consists of integers array[i] where i is within domain of the "indexVar". When indexVar is bound to the value v, the value of the resulting variable is array[v]. The operator "oper" defines the type of relationships between "array[indexVar]" and "value"

Parameters:
array - an array of integers.
indexVar - a constrained integer variable whose domain serves as an index into the "array".
Returns:
a constraint

element

Constraint element(int[] array,
                   Var indexVar,
                   Oper oper,
                   Var var)
Returns a constraint: array[indexVar] var Here "array[indexVar]" denotes a constrained integer variable, which domain consists of integers array[i] where i is within domain of the "indexVar". When indexVar is bound to the value v, the value of the resulting variable is array[v]. The operator "oper" defines the type of relationships between "array[indexVar]" and "var"

Parameters:
array - an array of integers.
indexVar - a constrained integer variable whose domain serves as an index into the "array".
Returns:
a constraint

globalCardinality

Constraint globalCardinality(Var[] vars,
                             Var[] cardinalityVars)
This method is similar to the globalCardinality(Var[] vars, Var[] cardinalityVars, int[] values) where the array “values” is fixed to an array of integers from 0 to (cardinalityVars.length – 1).

Parameters:
vars - the array of Vars
cardinalityVars - the array of Vars.
Returns:
constraint that sets relationships between "vars and "cardinalityVars" such that "cardinalityVars[i]" is equal to a number of occurrences of the value "i" among the constrained variables from "vars"

globalCardinality

Constraint globalCardinality(Var[] vars,
                             Var[] cardinalityVars,
                             int[] values)
This method counts the numbers of occurrences of integer values from a given array "values" among the constrained variables from a given array "vars" and associates these numbers with a given array “cardinalityVars”. More precisely, for each i from 0 to (values.lengh-1), cardinalityVars[i] is equal to the number of occurrences of values[i] in the array "vars". The arrays “cardinalityVars” and "values" should have the same size.

Parameters:
vars - the array of Vars
cardinalityVars - the array of Vars.
values - the array of values whose cardinality of occurrences in "vars" is in consideration.
Returns:
constraint that sets relationships between "vars and "cardinalityVars" as they are related to "values"
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - if arrays “cardinalityVars” and "values" have different sizes.

globalCardinality

Constraint globalCardinality(Var[] vars,
                             Var[] cardinalityVars,
                             Var[] valueVars)
This method counts the numbers of occurrences of integer values that may instantiate variables of a given array "valueVars" among the constrained variables from a given array "vars" and associates these numbers with a given array “cardinalityVars”. More precisely, for each i from 0 to (valueVars.lengh-1), cardinalityVars[i] is equal to the number of occurrences of valueVars[i] in the array "vars". The arrays “cardinalityVars” and "valueVarss" should have the same size – otherwise a RuntimeException will be thrown.

Parameters:
vars - the array of Vars
cardinalityVars - the array of Vars.
valueVars - the array of values whose cardinality of occurrences in "vars" is in consideration.
Returns:
constraint that sets relationships between "vars and "cardinalityVars" as they are related to "values"
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - if arrays “cardinalityVars” and "values" have different sizes.

Parameters:

var

Var var(java.lang.String name,
        int[] domain)
Creates a Var with the name "name" and domain containing the values in the array "domain" of the default domain type, adds this variable to the problem, and returns the newly added Var. The variable will be created with the default domain type or by the latest call of the method setDomainType().

Parameters:
name - the name for the new Var.
domain - an array specifying the values in the domain for the new Var.
Returns:
the Var variable created and added to the problem.

var

Var var(java.lang.String name,
        int min,
        int max)
Creates a Var with the name "name" and domain [min;max] of the default domain type, adds this variable to the problem, and returns the newly added Var. The variable will be created with the default domain type or by the latest call of the method setDomainType().

Parameters:
name - the name for the new Var.
min - the minimum value in the domain for the new Var.
max - the maximum value in the domain for the new Var.
Returns:
the Var variable created and added to the problem.

varArray

Var[] varArray(java.lang.String name,
               int min,
               int max,
               int size)
Creates an array of Var variables with the name "name" and domains [min;max] of the default domain type, adds this array of variables to the problem, and returns the newly added Var array. The "size" parameter specifies how many Var variables are contained in this new array. The variables will be created with the default domain type or as defined by the latest call of the method setDomainType().

Parameters:
name - the name for the new Var array.
min - the minimum value in the domains for the new Vars in the new Var array.
max - the maximum value in the domain for the new Vars in the new Var array.
size - the number of Vars in the new Var array.
Returns:
the array of Var variables created and added to the problem.

varSet

VarSet varSet(java.lang.String name,
              int min,
              int max)
              throws java.lang.Exception
Creates a constrained set variable VarSet with the name "name" and domain of integer values from "min" to "max" inclusive. This interface show how to create a new constrained set variable which, when bound, is equal to a set of elements. The domain of a constrained set variable is a set of Sets that consist of regular integers.The cardinality of a set constrained variable is an integer constrained variable.

Parameters:
name -
min -
max -
Returns:
a new VarSet variable
Throws:
java.lang.Exception
